titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Emily Hall Tremaine Papers, 1890-2000, in the Archives of American Art AAA.trememil
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Judy Ng
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record 256320.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-07-13T18:01-0400

did.abstract: The papers of art collector Emily Hall Tremaine measure 8.9 linear feet and date from 1890 to 2000. Found within the papers are biographical materials on the Hall, von Romberg, and Tremaine families, including a sound cassette on the Tremaines; personal correspondence; art collection files, which include inventory binders, records of sales and donations, artist files, exhibition loan files, and reproduction request files; 2 scrapbooks documenting Tremaine’s first marriage to Baron Maximilian von Romberg; and photographs of Tremaine, her family and friends, and works of art from her collection. There are also materials related the 1984 exhibition The Tremaine collection: 20th Century Masters at the Wadsworth Athenaeum, including a video recording of Philip Johnson’s exhibition lecture.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers were donated in 2006 by Tremine’s step-grandson, Burton G. Tremaine III.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Also found in the Archives of American Art is an oral history interview with Emily Hall Tremaine conducted by Paul Cummings, January 24, 1973.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed and a finding aid prepared by Judy Ng in 2015, with funding provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Emily Hall Tremaine papers, 1890-2000. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C. Research Center. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice. Contact Reference Services for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Emily Hall Tremaine papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. They may be used for research, study, and scholarship. Authorization to quote, publish, or reproduce for purposes of publication requires written permission from Burton G. Tremaine III.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Art collector Emily Hall Tremaine (1908-1987) lived in New York City and Madison, Connecticut and was known for having assembled one of the most noteworthy collections of post World War II art focused on modernist, pop, and contemporary artists.

Tremaine was born in Butte, Montana to mining executive William Hubbard Hall and his wife, Elizabeth Smith Hall. Her first marriage to Baron Maximilian von Romberg was well publicized in the society pages of the time and ended with the Baron’s death in a plane accident in 1938. Her second marriage to sugar heir Adolph B. Spreckels Jr. ended in divorce in 1940.

While Tremaine collected art in the 1930s, it was not until her 1945 marriage to industrial executive Burton Tremaine that she began acquiring works in earnest. Together, the Tremaines assembled a collection that initially focused on American and European modern artists and would eventually include emerging pop and contemporary art. Their first purchase was Piet Mondrian’s unfinished painting, Victory Boogie Woogie, now owned by the Gemeentemuseum. The collection would eventually number over 400 art works and range from paintings by Picasso, Kandinsky, and Georges Braque to works by Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, and Jean-Michel Basquiat. While single pieces were sold, traded, or donated throughout Tremaine's active collecting years, the bulk of the collection was sold at auction in 1988 and 1991 to raise funds for the Emily Hall Tremaine Foundation. Tremaine died from complications of emphysema in 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of art collector Emily Hall Tremaine measure 8.9 linear feet and date from 1890 to 2000. Found within the papers are biographical materials on the Hall, von Romberg, and Tremaine families, including a sound cassette on the Tremaines; personal correspondence; art collection files, which include inventory binders, records of sales and donations, artist files, exhibition loan files, and reproduction request files; 2 scrapbooks documenting Tremaine’s first marriage to Baron Maximilian von Romberg; and photographs of Tremaine, her family and friends, and works of art from her collection. There are also materials related the 1984 exhibition The Tremaine collection: 20th Century Masters at the Wadsworth Athenaeum, including a video recording of Philip Johnson’s exhibition lecture.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 8 series.

list.item: Series 3: Art Collection Files, 1950-1980 (0.6 linear feet; Boxes 1, 9)
Series 4: Artist Files, 1936-2000 (4.6 linear feet; Boxes 2-6, 9)
Series 5: Exhibition Loan Files, 1960-2000 (1.5 linear feet; Boxes 6-7)
Series 6: Reproduction Request Files, 1965-1988 (0.6 linear feet; Box 8)
Series 8: Photographic Materials, 1890-1997 (0.8 linear feet; Boxes 8, 10-11)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical materials include a booklet reprinting the letters of Tremaine’s uncle, Horace Hall, biographical information on her grandfather, Stephen Smith, and the banking account book of her father, William Hall. There are also bookplates from Tremaine’s first husband, Baron Maximilian von Romberg; a sound cassette recording documenting the family of her third husband, Burton Tremaine; and an undated watercolor portrait of Emily Hall as a child.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by document type.

physdesc.physfacet: Handwritten note on original cassette: "How the Tremaines Got Here First"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes a number of letters from Tremaine’s mother, Elizabeth Hall, and her sister, Jane Noble, as well as miscellaneous notes and letters from Tremaine’s three husbands, Maximilian von Romberg, Adolph Spreckels, and Burton Tremaine. There are also miscellaneous letters and cards from other family and friends, including reproductions of artwork from Tremaine’s collection that were sent as Christmas cards.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials have retained arrangement by document type and sender.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Art collection files consists of three inventory binders and an index card file cataloging over 400 pieces of American and European art collected by Tremaine. These documents record dates of purchase, sale prices, insurance and market values, provenance, condition, exhibition loans, and reproductions in publications. The index cards are divided into two sections, paintings sold or donated prior to Tremaine’s death, and works of art remaining in the collection after her death. There are also subject files on Native American art, and primitive and pop art, as well as miscellaneous sale invoices and receipts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by document type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 9, Folder 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paintings sold or donated before Tremaine's death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paintings in collection after Tremaine's death.

did.unittitle: Oversize Inventory Binder from Box 1, Folder 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artist Files contain correspondence with artists, galleries, and museums, as well as printed and photographic material documenting works of art in the Tremaine collection. Over 200 artists whose works were purchased, sold, traded, or donated, or whose works were considered for purchase, are included. Artists range from modernists Georges Braque, Paul Klee, Jean Arp, and Marcel Duchamp to pop and contemporary artists such as Andy Warhol, Mark Rothko, Yves Klein, Dan Flavin, Michael Heizer, and Jim Dine. There is also significant research and documentation on the provenance, restoration, and sale of Piet Mondrian’s Victory Boogie Woogie, which was sold in 1988.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged alphabetically by surname of the artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Information on the work "Black Rose."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, explanatory charts, writings, and photographs of work by Perle Fine. Oversized materials housed in Box 9, Folder 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 9, Folder 2.

did.unittitle: Oversize Piet Mondrian Charts and Periodical from Box 4, Folder 28 and Box 5, Folder 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Exhibition loan files consist of correspondence, lists, forms/invoices, and printed and photographic material tracking works of art from the Tremaine collection loaned for museum and gallery exhibitions. There are also extensive files documenting the 1984 exhibition of close to 150 works from the Tremaine collection organized by the Wadsworth Atheneum, including a video lecture by Philip Johnson.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically according to the year works of art were returned to the collection.

physdesc.physfacet: Handwritten note on original cassette: "Philip Johnson - Feb. 25, 1984 Wadsworth Atheneum"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproduction request files consist of correspondence, forms/invoices, and printed and photographic material tracking works of art from the Tremaine collection published in exhibition catalogs, periodicals, and newspapers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically and filed by year of reproduction request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The two scrapbooks consist of newspaper clippings and photographs documenting news of the courtship and marriage of Emily Hall to her first husband, Baron Maximilian von Romberg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographic materials are of Emily Hall Tremaine, her first husband, Maximilian von Romberg, and her second husband, Burton Tremaine, as well as two photo albums documenting works of art in the Tremaine collection. Photographs dating from Emily’s first marriage to von Romberg include photos of their friends and interiors of their residence, Brunninghausen. There are also photographs of the Tremaines' residences and Frank Lloyd Wright designs for a resort in Meteor Crater.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by subject and document type.
